smell_analysis.justification: Reviewed all pages that clearly show diagrams (use case, class, activity, state, database). Each contains visible elements and labels; no page appears to be an empty diagram.

Checked the use case diagrams on pages 2 and 3. No use case oval is explicitly shown as isolated from all actors in the visible content, and the overview-style list on page 1 is excluded by the rule note. Therefore no unambiguous violation was found.

On the use case diagrams (pages 2 and 3), the use case names appear to describe distinct activities (e.g., 'Vaata aktiivseid autosid' vs 'Vaata kõiki autosid', and separate change actions like 'Registreeri auto', 'Lõpeta auto', 'Lisa auto'). No two or more use cases with the same actor clearly describe the same activity.

The package/overview diagram on page 1 lists subsystems and registers, but does not visibly show multiple distinct model elements with the same primary name within the same package. Any repeated classifier-type or package-qualified text appears to be display metadata per the clarification. No explicit duplicate elements were found.

Reviewed the database diagrams on pages 14-19. The tables and columns shown do not explicitly indicate redundant storage of the same data value across multiple tables without an FK. Identically themed columns such as codes or names appear to be normal identifiers rather than stated denormalized copies. No clear G6.3 case is visible.

Use case names on pages 2 and 3 consistently use an active verb form at the start (e.g., 'Tuvasta', 'Vaata', 'Registreeri', 'Lõpeta', 'Muuda', 'Lisa', 'Unusta'). No inconsistent form across these use cases is visible.

The state diagram on page 9 shows states such as 'Ootel', 'Aktiivne', 'Mitteaktiivne', 'Lõpetatud', and 'Unustatud'. The visible content does not unambiguously show a state with no incoming path from the initial state or other states. Without a clearly unreachable state, G15.1 is not triggered.

The activity diagram on page 4 lists actions like 'Vaata kõiki autosid...', 'Otsi autot...', 'Vali auto', and 'Lõpeta valitud auto' with decision points. The visible content does not clearly indicate any action that cannot be reached. No explicit unreachable action was found.

Across class diagrams (pages 5-13), multiplicities such as '0..*', '1', and '0..1' are shown next to relationships. The database diagrams (pages 14-19) use FK-style notation that is exempt per interpretation rules. No relationship is visibly drawn in UML style without multiplicity indicators at both ends.

Counted central elements per diagram. The use case diagrams have 4 and about 7 use cases (pages 2 and 3), the state diagram has about 5 named states (page 9), and class/database diagrams on pages 5-19 appear to show fewer than 10 classes/tables each (e.g., page 15 shows roughly 9 classifier tables). No single diagram clearly reaches 10 or more central elements.

No class or table is shown with 6 or more distinct, separately drawn relationship lines on any single class/database diagram. Based on the visible listings and referenced related elements on pages 5-13 and 14-19, connections appear below this threshold, and no explicit six-line hub is evident.

The PDF does not provide an unambiguous visual case where two related elements are placed at a distance more than twice the average distance between elements on the same diagram. Without a clearly measurable outlier spacing, this rule is treated as not violated.

All visible use case names on pages 2 and 3 start with active verbs. The activity actions on page 4 also start with verbs such as 'Vaata', 'Otsi', 'Vali', and 'Lõpeta'. No use case or action name is visibly starting with a non-verb.

Reviewed names of visible classes, tables, attributes/columns, and use cases across the document. No name of 3 or fewer characters is clearly shown as a central element name; common short tokens appear within longer names (e.g., 'isik_id') rather than as standalone element names.

Class names on the class diagrams (pages 5-13) start with uppercase letters and appear singular (e.g., 'Isik', 'Auto', 'Töötaja', 'Klient'). No class name is visibly lowercase-initial or plural in a way that clearly violates N3.1.

Attribute and column names shown in the class and database diagrams (pages 5-19) appear to start with lowercase letters (e.g., 'eesnimi', 'perenimi', 'reg_aeg', 'auto_kood'). No attribute/column name starting with an uppercase letter is clearly visible.
Database table names shown on pages 14-19 appear singular (e.g., 'Isik', 'Kasutajakonto', 'Auto', 'Riik', 'Auto_mark'). No plural table name is clearly presented as an individual entity table.

No class, table, attribute, or use case name visibly uses a type-indicating prefix like 'tbl_', 'uc_', or 'str'. The only prefixes shown are PK/FK/index annotations in database diagrams, which are allowed by the rule note.
